0.1</sub></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">&gt;0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.77</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.75</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong>\n<a name=\"apj404369t5fn1\" id=\"apj404369t5fn1\"></a><sup> a</sup>Number of galaxies used in the weak lensing analysis in each filter. For the multi-filter samples, <em>N</em> is the number of <em>unique</em> galaxies.\n<a name=\"apj404369t5fn2\" id=\"apj404369t5fn2\"></a><sup> b</sup>SExtractor <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt> magnitude limits used to define the galaxy sample.\n<a name=\"apj404369t5fn3\" id=\"apj404369t5fn3\"></a><sup> c</sup>Minimum Ellipto size <em>Q<sub>xx</sub></em> + <em>Q<sub>yy</sub></em> used to define the galaxy sample.\n<a name=\"apj404369t5fn4\" id=\"apj404369t5fn4\"></a><sup> d</sup>The source redshift at which 1/\u03a3<sub>crit</sub> is the same as the effective value computed by integration over the source galaxy redshift distribution, as described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s5-3\">5.3</a>.\n<a name=\"apj404369t5fn5\" id=\"apj404369t5fn5\"></a><sup> e</sup>Best-fit NFW profile parameters: mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>. Errors are one-parameter, 1\u03c3 values, as determined where \u0394\u03c7<sup>2</sup> = 1. The uncertainties on <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> are rounded off to the nearest 0.1 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>. Note that for most of the cases (primarily B-mode fits) where there is no significant mass detection, we provide only a 1\u03c3 lower limit on <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>, which is otherwise not constrained on the high side even at 1\u03c3, up to the upper bound value <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> = 10<sup>4</sup> that we have checked. Joint two-parameter error contours for select samples are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f13\">13</a>.\n<a name=\"apj404369t5fn6\" id=\"apj404369t5fn6\"></a><sup> f</sup>\u03c7<sup>2</sup> per degree of freedom (dof) relative to a null hypothesis of zero shear. (This is <em>not</em> the \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof of the NFW fit, which is very close to one in all cases.) <em>P</em> is the probability of exceeding the observed \u03c7<sup>2</sup>/dof. The number of degrees of freedom for this \u03c7<sup>2</sup> test is always 20, i.e., the number of radial bins plotted in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f10\">10</a>\u2013<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f12\">12</a>.\n<a name=\"apj404369t5fn7\" id=\"apj404369t5fn7\"></a><sup> g</sup>Fit results derived from combined weak-plus-strong lensing (\"SL\") constraints. \"(s)\" denotes the case where we estimated the dark matter mass within the Einstein radius by subtracting off just a stellar mass contribution, while \"(sg)\" is the case where we also subtracted off an estimated gas mass contribution. See Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-1\">6.1</a> for details.\n<a name=\"apj404369t5fn8\" id=\"apj404369t5fn8\"></a><sup> h</sup>Fit results derived from combined weak lensing (<em>i</em> + <em>r</em> + <em>z</em>), strong lensing (SL(sg)), cluster velocity dispersion (\u03c3<sub><em>c</em></sub>), and cluster richness (<em>N</em><sub>200</sub>) constraints. See Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-2\">6.2</a> for details.</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t5_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/742/1/48\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t5_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Our NFW fitting results are shown in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f10\">10</a> and\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f11\">11</a> and detailed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t5\">5</a>. We show results for both the tangential and B-mode shear components. As lensing does not produce a B-mode shear signal, these results provide a check on systematic errors and should be consistent with zero in the absence of significant systematics. For all of our filters, our B-mode shear results are indeed consistent with no detected mass, as the best-fit <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> is within about 1\u03c3 of zero. On the other hand, for the tangential shear results in the <em>r</em>, <em>i</em>, and <em>z</em> filters, we do indeed obtain detections of non-zero <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> at the better than 1.5\u03c3 level. In the <em>g</em> filter we do not detect a non-zero <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>. Comparing the weak lensing results from the different filters serves as a useful check of the robustness of our lensing-based cluster mass measurement, in particular as the images in the different filters are subject to quite different PSF patterns, as shown earlier in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f9\">9</a>. Though the mass errors are large, the <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> values from the <em>r</em>-, <em>i</em>-, and <em>z</em>-band weak lensing NFW fits are nonetheless consistent with each other and with the masses derived earlier from the velocity dispersion and maxBCG richness analyses. Moreover, independent of the NFW fits, we have also derived probabilities (of exceeding the observed \u03c7<sup>2</sup>) that our <em>binned</em> shear profiles are consistent with the null hypothesis of zero shear. As shown in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t5\">5</a>, we see that the B-mode profiles are in all cases consistent with zero, as expected, but that the tangential profiles for the <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> filters are not consistent with the null hypothesis at about the 2\u03c3 level (probabilities \u22480.06), thus providing model-independent evidence for a weak lensing detection of the cluster mass.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f10\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f10\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f10_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 10.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 10.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f10_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 10.</strong>\u00a0Points with error bars show the tangential (top) and B-mode (bottom) radial shear profiles for the galaxy sample used for weak lensing analysis in the <em>i</em> (left) and <em>r</em> (right) filters. In each panel, the solid curve shows the shear profile for the best-fitting NFW mass density profile, as determined via the procedure described in Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s5-3\">5.3</a>. The dashed horizontal lines indicate zero shear. The best-fit NFW parameters and details of the galaxy sample are given in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t5\">5</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f11\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f11\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f11_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 11.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 11.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f11_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 11.</strong>\u00a0Similar to Figure <a href=\"#apj404369f10\">10</a>, but for the <em>z</em> (left) and <em>g</em> (right) filters.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj404369s5-4\" name=\"apj404369s5-4\">5.4.\u00a0Combining Weak Lensing Constraints from Different Filters</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Here we will combine the weak lensing shear profile information from the different filters <em>griz</em> in order to improve the constraints on the NFW parameters, in particular on <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>. The main complication here is that although the ellipticity measurement errors are independent among the different filters, the most important error for the shear measurement is the intrinsic galaxy shape noise, which is correlated among filters because a subset of the galaxies is common to two or more filters, and for these galaxies we expect their shapes to be fairly similar in the different filters. In particular, we find that the covariance of the true galaxy ellipticities between filters is large, for example, the covariance of <em>e</em><sub>1</sub> between the <em>i</em> and <em>r</em> filters, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"${\\rm Cov}(e_{1,i},e_{1,r}) = ({1}/{N}) \\sum (e_{1,i}-\\bar{e}_{1,i}) (e_{1,r}-\\bar{e}_{1,r})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\rm Cov}(e_{1,i},e_{1,r}) = ({1}/{N}) \\sum (e_{1,i}-\\bar{e}_{1,i}) (e_{1,r}-\\bar{e}_{1,r})</script></span></span>, is about 0.9 times the variance of <em>e</em><sub>1</sub> in the <em>i</em> and <em>r</em> filters individually. The same holds true for <em>e</em><sub>2</sub> and for the other filters as well. We will not attempt to use a full covariance matrix approach to deal with the galaxy shape correlations when we combine the data from two or more filters. Instead, we take a simpler approach of scaling the measured standard deviation of the shear (the \u03c3<sub>\u03b3</sub> used to calculate \u03c7<sup>2</sup> in Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd16\">16</a>)) by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"$\\sqrt{N/N_{{\\rm unique}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sqrt{N/N_{{\\rm unique}}}</script></span></span>, where <em>N</em> is the total number of galaxies in a given multi-filter sample and <em>N</em><sub>unique</sub> is the number of unique galaxies in the same sample. This is equivalent to rescaling \u03c7<sup>2</sup> in the NFW fit to correspond to <em>N</em><sub>unique</sub> degrees of freedom instead of <em>N</em>. We have verified using least-squares fits to Monte Carlo simulations of NFW shear profiles that this simple approach gives the correct fit uncertainties on <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> when the mock galaxy data contain duplicate galaxies, with identical <em>e</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>e</em><sub>2</sub> values, simulating the case of <em>completely</em> correlated intrinsic galaxy shapes among filters. Note that our approach is conservative and will slightly overestimate the errors because the galaxy shapes in the real data are about 90% correlated, not fully correlated, among filters.</p><p>Before fitting the combined shear data from multiple filters, we make one additional multiplicative rescaling of the shear values, so that all filters will have the same effective value of 1/\u03a3<sub>crit</sub>, corresponding to a fiducial effective source redshift <em>z</em><sub>crit</sub> = 0.7. This correction is small, with the largest being a factor of 1.18 for the <em>z</em>-band data. The results of the NFW fits for the multi-filter samples are given in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t5\">5</a>, where we have tried the filter combinations <em>i</em>+<em>r</em>, <em>i</em> + <em>r</em> + <em>z</em>, and <em>i</em> + <em>r</em> + <em>z</em> + <em>g</em>. We see that these multi-filter samples all provide better fractional errors on <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> compared to those from the single-filter data. Also, as expected, the B-mode results in all cases are consistent with no detected <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and zero shear. For our final weak lensing results, we adopt the NFW parameters from the <em>i</em> + <em>r</em> + <em>z</em> sample, as it provides the best fractional error (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma _{M_{200}}/M_{200} \\approx 0.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma _{M_{200}}/M_{200} \\approx 0.5</script></span></span>) on <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>; we obtain <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> = 5.0<sup>+2.9</sup><sub>\u2212 2.3</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>, and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> = 4.9<sup>+3.9</sup><sub>\u2212 2.2</sub>. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f12\">12</a> shows the shear profile data and best-fit results for the <em>i</em> + <em>r</em> + <em>z</em> sample. This final weak lensing value for <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> agrees well with the earlier values of <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> derived from the cluster galaxy velocity dispersion (assuming no velocity bias) and from the cluster richness <em>N</em><sub>200</sub>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f12\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f12\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f12_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 12.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 12.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f12_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 12.</strong>\u00a0Similar to Figure <a href=\"#apj404369f10\">10</a>, but for the multi-filter <em>i</em> + <em>r</em> + <em>z</em> sample. For the tangential shear profile fits in the top panel, the long-dashed curve gives the results using weak lensing only, while the dotted and solid curves give the results using combined weak plus strong lensing. The dotted curve is for the case where we estimated the dark matter mass within the Einstein radius by subtracting off just a stellar mass contribution, while the solid curve is for the case where we also subtracted off an estimated gas mass contribution. See Sections <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s5-4\">5.4</a>,\u00a0<a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-1\">6.1</a>, and Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t5\">5</a> for details.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f12\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f12\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f12\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f12\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj404369s6\" name=\"apj404369s6\">6.\u00a0COMBINED CONSTRAINTS ON CLUSTER MASS AND CONCENTRATION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj404369s6-1\" name=\"apj404369s6-1\">6.1.\u00a0Combining Strong and Weak Lensing</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In this section, we combine the strong lensing and weak lensing information together in order to further improve our constraints on the NFW profile parameters, in particular on the concentration parameter <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>. The addition of the strong lensing information provides constraints on the mass within the Einstein radius, close to the cluster center, thereby allowing us to better measure the central concentration of the NFW profile and improve the uncertainties on the concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>. Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>) incorporated the strong lensing information in the form of a constraint on the Einstein radius due to only the dark matter distribution of the cluster, and they specifically excluded the contribution of (stellar) baryons to the Einstein radius. Their intent, as well as ours in this paper (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-2\">6.2</a>), is to compare the observed cluster NFW concentration to that predicted from dark-matter-<em>only</em> simulations. Thus the contribution of baryonic matter should be removed, most importantly in the central region within the Einstein radius, where baryonic effects are the largest due in particular to the presence of the BCG. In practice with the present data we can do this separation of the baryonic contribution only for the strong lensing constraint, and strictly speaking the weak lensing profile results from the total mass distribution rather than from dark matter alone.</p><p>Here we combine the strong and weak lensing data using an analogous but somewhat simpler method compared to that of Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>), specifically by adding a second term to \u03c7<sup>2</sup> (Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd16\">16</a>)) that describes the constraint on the dark matter (only) mass within the observed Einstein radius:\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd17\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd17.gif\" alt=\"Equation (17)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} \\chi ^2 &=& \\sum _{i=1}^{N} \\frac{[\\gamma _i - \\gamma _{{\\rm NFW}}(r_i; M_{200},c_{200})]^2}{\\sigma _\\gamma ^2}\\nonumber\\\\ &&+ \\frac{[M_{{\\rm DM}}({< }\\theta _E) - M_{{\\rm NFW}}({< }\\theta _E; M_{200},c_{200})]^2}{\\sigma _{M_{{\\rm DM}}(< \\theta _E)}^2},\\qquad \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t17\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub> = 7<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />53 is the observed Einstein radius due to the <em>total</em> cluster mass distribution, <em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>) is the dark matter (only) mass within \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>, and <em>M</em><sub>NFW</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>; <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>, <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>) is the mass within \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub> of an NFW profile with mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>, concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>, redshift <em>z</em> = 0.38, and source redshift <em>z</em> = 0.9057. <em>M</em><sub>NFW</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>; <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>, <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>) is derived based on Equation (13) of Wright &amp; Brainerd (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r72\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r72\">2000</a>). As obtained earlier in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s4\">4</a>, we estimate <em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>) by subtracting estimates of the stellar mass and hot gas mass from the total mass within \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>, obtaining <em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>) = (1.18 \u00b1 0.2) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>13</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> when subtracting off both stellar and gas mass, or <em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>) = (1.33 \u00b1 0.2) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>13</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> when subtracting off only stellar mass. The former is our best estimate of <em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>), while the latter serves as an upper limit on <em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>) and hence on the best-fit concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>. We also conservatively estimate the error on <em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>) to be one of the stellar mass/gas mass components added in quadrature to the uncertainty on the total <em>M</em><sub>EIN</sub> from Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s4\">4</a>.</p><p>We apply the combined strong-plus-weak lensing analysis to our best weak lensing sample, the multi-filter <em>i</em> + <em>r</em> + <em>z</em> data set. The fit results are given in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t5\">5</a> and shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f12\">12</a>. We find <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> = 4.9<sup>+2.9</sup><sub>\u2212 2.2</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> solar masses, nearly identical to the final weak lensing result. We also get a concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> = 5.5<sup>+2.7</sup><sub>\u2212 1.6</sub>, again consistent with the final weak lensing fit, but with a 30% improvement in the error on <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>, demonstrating the usefulness of adding the strong lensing information to constrain the NFW concentration. Using the upper limit <em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>) value (with only stellar mass subtracted) gives nearly the same <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> = 4.8<sup>+2.8</sup><sub>\u2212 2.2</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>, while the resulting NFW concentration is higher, as expected, with <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> = 6.2<sup>+3.2</sup><sub>\u2212 1.7</sub>, but still consistent with the fit using our best estimate of <em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>(&lt; \u03b8<sub><em>E</em></sub>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apj404369s6-2\" name=\"apj404369s6-2\">6.2.\u00a0Combining Lensing, Velocity Dispersion, and Richness Constraints</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In the above sections, we have obtained quite consistent constraints on the cluster mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> using three independent techniques: (1) <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>(lensing) = 4.9<sup>+2.9</sup><sub>\u2212 2.2</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> from combined weak + strong lensing (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-1\">6.1</a>); (2) <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>(\u03c3<sub><em>c</em></sub>) = 5.79<sup>+2.22</sup><sub>\u2212 1.99</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> from the cluster galaxy velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><em>c</em></sub> (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-4\">3.4</a>; assuming no velocity bias, <em>b<sub>v</sub></em> = 1); and (3) <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>(<em>N</em><sub>200</sub>) = (4.6 \u00b1 2.1) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> from the maxBCG-defined cluster richness <em>N</em><sub>200</sub> (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-2\">3.2</a>). We note that these methods are subject to different assumptions and systematic errors. For example, the velocity-dispersion-based mass estimate assumes that the cluster is virialized, an assumption supported by the Gaussian-shaped velocity distribution of the cluster members shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f7\">7</a>. Also, the richness-based mass estimate relies on the <em>N</em><sub>200</sub>\u2013<em>M</em><sub>200</sub> calibration (Johnston et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r36\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r36\">2007</a>) obtained for SDSS maxBCG clusters at lower redshifts <em>z</em> = 0.1\u20130.3 and assumes that this calibration remains valid for our cluster at <em>z</em> = 0.38. It is encouraging that we are obtaining a cluster mass measurement that appears to be robust to these disparate assumptions and that shows good agreement among multiple independent methods.</p><p>We will therefore combine the results from the different techniques in order to obtain final constraints on <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> that are significantly improved over what any one technique permits. Specifically, we can add the <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> constraints from the velocity dispersion and richness measurements as additional terms to the weak + strong lensing \u03c7<sup>2</sup> (Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd17\">17</a>)):\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd18\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd18.gif\" alt=\"Equation (18)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} \\chi ^2 & = & \\sum _{i=1}^{N} \\frac{[\\gamma _i - \\gamma _{{\\rm NFW}}(r_i; M_{200},c_{200})]^2}{\\sigma _\\gamma ^2}\\nonumber\\\\ &&+ \\frac{[M_{{\\rm DM}}(< \\theta _E) - M_{{\\rm NFW}}(< \\theta _E; M_{200},c_{200})]^2}{\\sigma _{M_{{\\rm DM}}(< \\theta _E)}^2} \\nonumber \\\\ &&+ \\frac{[M_{200}(\\sigma _c)-M_{200}]^2}{\\sigma _{M_{200}(\\sigma _c)}^2} + \\frac{[M_{200}(N_{200})-M_{200}]^2}{\\sigma _{M_{200}(N_{200})}^2}.\\qquad \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t18\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Minimizing this overall \u03c7<sup>2</sup> results in the final best-fitting NFW parameters, <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> = 5.1<sup>+1.3</sup><sub>\u2212 1.3</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> = 5.4<sup>+1.4</sup><sub>\u2212 1.1</sub>. These results are consistent with the final lensing-based values <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>(lensing) = 4.9<sup>+2.9</sup><sub>\u2212 2.2</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>(lensing) = 5.5<sup>+2.7</sup><sub>\u2212 1.6</sub>, but have errors nearly a factor of two smaller. Note that these quoted errors are one-parameter, 1\u03c3 uncertainties; we plot the joint two-parameter, 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3 contours in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f13\">13</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f13\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f13\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f13_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 13.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 13.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f13_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 13.</strong>\u00a0Confidence contours for the best-fitting NFW mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>, obtained by combining the lensing, velocity dispersion, and cluster richness constraints, as described in Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-2\">6.2</a>. The two-parameter, 1\u03c3 contours are shown in solid blue, while the 2\u03c3 contours are shown in hatched blue. The outer dashed contours show the two-parameter, 2\u03c3 constraints derived solely from the weak + strong lensing analysis of Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-1\">6.1</a>. Also, as described in Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-2\">6.2</a>, the three mostly horizontal curves show the concentration vs. mass relation at <em>z</em> = 0.4 for (bottom) clusters overall from \u039bCDM simulations, (middle) lensing-selected clusters from simulations, and (top) a real lensing cluster sample from Oguri et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f13\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f13\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f13\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f13\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We also note that for the three methods, weak lensing, velocity dispersion, and cluster richness, the corresponding NFW parameters result from the <em>total</em> mass distribution, consisting of both dark matter and baryonic (stellar plus hot gas) components. Dark matter is dominant over the bulk of the cluster, while baryons can have a significant effect in the cluster core (e.g., Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>). As described earlier (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-1\">6.1</a>), we have thus subtracted off the baryonic contribution to the strong lensing constraint as the intent is to compare (see below) our cluster concentration value against those from dark-matter-only simulations. Note that we have not isolated the dark matter contribution for the other three methods and cannot easily do so. For weak lensing, the shear profile is sensitive to the total mass distribution, not just to dark matter. For the velocity dispersion method, the galaxies act as test particles in the overall cluster potential, which is, again, due to both dark matter and baryons. For the cluster richness method, the Johnston et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r36\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r36\">2007</a>) <em>N</em><sub>200</sub>\u2013<em>M</em><sub>200</sub> relation we use was derived from stacked cluster weak lensing shear profile fits, including a BCG contribution but otherwise no other baryonic components; thus again the <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> value is essentially for the total mass distribution. Nonetheless, the bulk of the baryonic contribution is in the cluster core and is accounted for via the strong lensing constraint, so we expect the comparison below of our cluster concentration value to those of dark matter simulations to be a reasonable exercise.</p><p>Recent analyses (e.g., Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>; Broadhurst &amp; Barkana <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r14\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r14\">2008</a>) of strong lensing clusters have indicated that these clusters are more concentrated than would be expected from \u039bCDM predictions, though others have argued that no discrepancy exists if baryonic effects are accounted for (Richard et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r64\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r64\">2010</a>). In the former case, Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>) found a concentration <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> \u2248 9 for the 10 strong lensing clusters in their analysis sample, compared to a value of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> \u2248 6 expected for strong-lensing-selected clusters or <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> \u2248 4 for clusters overall (e.g., Broadhurst &amp; Barkana <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r14\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r14\">2008</a>; Oguri &amp; Blandford <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r58\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r58\">2009</a>). We illustrate these different concentration values in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f13\">13</a>. We use Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd17\">17</a>) of Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>), <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn17.gif\" alt=\"$\\bar{c}_{\\rm vir}({\\rm sim}) = ({7.85}/{(1+z)^{0.71}})(M_{\\rm vir}/2.78 \\times 10^{12} \\,M_\\odot)^{-0.081}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\bar{c}_{\\rm vir}({\\rm sim}) = ({7.85}/{(1+z)^{0.71}})(M_{\\rm vir}/2.78 \\times 10^{12} \\,M_\\odot)^{-0.081}</script></span></span>, which comes from the \u039bCDM <em>N</em>-body simulations of Duffy et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r24\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r24\">2008</a>), to show the typical concentration of clusters overall, and multiply by a factor of 1.5 (Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>) to show the higher concentration expected for lensing-selected clusters. We also use Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd18\">18</a>) of Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>), <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"$\\bar{c}_{\\rm vir}({\\rm fit}) = ({12.4}/{(1+z)^{0.71}})(M_{\\rm vir}/10^{15} \\,M_\\odot)^{-0.081}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\bar{c}_{\\rm vir}({\\rm fit}) = ({12.4}/{(1+z)^{0.71}})(M_{\\rm vir}/10^{15} \\,M_\\odot)^{-0.081}</script></span></span>, to show the fit results for their cluster sample. In these relations, we set <em>z</em> = 0.4 to match the redshift of our cluster. Moreover, we convert from the <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>, <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> convention used by Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>) to our <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>, <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> convention, using the detailed relations found in Appendix C of Hu &amp; Kravtsov (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r33\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r33\">2003</a>) or in the Appendix of Johnston et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r36\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r36\">2007</a>). For the plotted <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> range, it turns out that <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> \u2248 0.83\u2009<em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>. From Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f13\">13</a>, we see that our best-fit value of <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> = 5.4<sup>+1.4</sup><sub>\u2212 1.1</sub> is most consistent with the nominal \u039bCDM concentration value for lensing-selected clusters, and does not suggest the need for a concentration excess in this particular case. It is likely that larger strong lensing cluster samples will be needed to more robustly compare the distribution of concentration values with the predictions of \u039bCDM models.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj404369s7\" name=\"apj404369s7\">7.\u00a0SOURCE GALAXY STAR FORMATION RATE</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We can use the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]3727 line in the calibrated spectra described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-3\">3.3</a> to estimate the SFR. As noted by Kennicutt (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r38\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r38\">1998</a>) the luminosities of forbidden lines like [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]3727 are not directly coupled to the ionizing luminosity and their excitation is also sensitive to abundance and the ionization state of the gas. However, the excitation of [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] is well behaved enough that it can be calibrated through H\u03b1 as an SFR tracer. This indirect calibration is very useful for studies of distant galaxies because [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]3727 can be observed out to redshifts <em>z</em> \u2248 1.6 and it has been measured in several large samples of faint galaxies (see references in Kennicutt <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r38\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r38\">1998</a>). If we know the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity then we can use Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd3\">3</a>) from Kennicutt (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r38\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r38\">1998</a>) to determine an SFR for the galaxy\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd19\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd19.gif\" alt=\"Equation (19)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} {\\rm SFR} (M_\\odot \\, {\\rm yr}^{-1}) = (1.4 \\pm 0.4) \\times 10^{-41} (L[{\\rm O}\\,\\mathsc{ii}])({\\rm ergs\\, s}^{-1}), \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t19\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where the uncertainty reflects the range between blue emission-line galaxies (lower limit) and more luminous spiral and irregular galaxies (upper limit).</p><p>As noted above, in order to extract the SFR we need to determine the total source flux from the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line. We determine this using\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd20\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd20.gif\" alt=\"Equation (20)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} f(\\nu)_{[{\\rm O}\\,\\mathsc{ii}]} = \\frac{f(\\nu)_L}{f(\\nu)_S}\\times f(\\nu)_I, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t20\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"$f(\\nu)_{[{\\rm O}\\,\\mathsc{ii}]}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">f(\\nu)_{[{\\rm O}\\,\\mathsc{ii}]}</script></span></span> is the total flux emitted by the source in the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line, <em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>L</em></sub> is the flux measured in the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line in each spectrum, <em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>S</em></sub> is the flux in the knot spectrum contained within the <em>i</em>-band filter band pass, and <em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>I</em></sub> is the flux from the source in the <em>i</em>-band.</p><p>Using the GALFIT-subtracted <em>i</em>-band image, we determine <em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>I</em></sub> by summing the flux in an annulus of width 3'' that encompasses the arcs. The flux <em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>L</em></sub> is measured by fitting a Gaussian plus a continuum to the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line in each spectrum and integrating the flux under the Gaussian fit. The flux <em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>S</em></sub> is calculated as follows. For each spectrum we first fit the continuum level; we then add the fitted continuum plus the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line flux and convolve it with the filter response curve for the SDSS <em>i</em>-band filter and integrate the convolved spectrum.</p><p>We have determined <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"$f(\\nu)_{[\\rm O\\,\\mathsc{ii}]}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">f(\\nu)_{[\\rm O\\,\\mathsc{ii}]}</script></span></span> separately for each knot that was targeted for spectra. The fluxes are listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t6\">6</a> for each knot. We convert <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"$f(\\nu)_{[\\rm O\\,\\mathsc{ii}]}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">f(\\nu)_{[\\rm O\\,\\mathsc{ii}]}</script></span></span> into an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity and then use Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd19\">19</a>) to determine an SFR for each knot. This rate is the raw rate, which must be scaled by the lens magnification <em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> to determine the true rate. We quote the SFR for the two values of <em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> that were determined in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s4\">4</a>. We assume one magnitude of extinction (Kennicutt <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r38\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r38\">1998</a>) and have corrected the measured [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity to account for this. This yields the SFRs listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t6\">6</a> for the two values of <em>f</em><sub>lens</sub>. The rate for knot A3 is higher by a factor of two compared to the others because it has a small <em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>S</em></sub> compared to the other knots but the value of <em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>L</em></sub> is quite similar to the other knots. This can be clearly seen in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f6\">6</a>. We can combine the measurements for the four knots using a simple average to quote an overall SFR. This yields values of SFR(<em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> = 49) = 4.6 \u00b1 0.7 and SFR(<em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> = 141) = 1.3 \u00b1 0.2.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj404369t6\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 6.</b>\u00a0Source Galaxy Star Formation Rates<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj404369t6fn1\">a</a></sup></p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369t6\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t6_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 6\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Knot</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"$f(\\nu)_{[\\rm O\\,\\mathsc{ii}]}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">f(\\nu)_{[\\rm O\\,\\mathsc{ii}]}</script></span></span></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>L</em></sub></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><em>f</em>(\u03bd)<sub><em>S</em></sub></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">SFR ((<em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> = 39) <em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">SFR ((<em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> = 141) <em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>)</th></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\u00a0</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>Hz<sup>\u22121</sup>)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u00a0</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u00a0</th></tr>\n</thead><tbody><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">A1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.06 \u00b1 0.04 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221215</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.71 \u00b1 0.06 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221216</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.36 \u00b1 0.02 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221228</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">3.9 \u00b1 1.1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">1.1 \u00b1 0.4</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">A2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.84 \u00b1 0.04 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221215</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.43 \u00b1 0.06 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221216</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.43 \u00b1 0.02 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221228</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">3.1 \u00b1 0.9</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">0.85 \u00b1 0.4</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">A3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2.09 \u00b1 0.10 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221215</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.28 \u00b1 0.06 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221216</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">0.51 \u00b1 0.01 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221228</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">7.7 \u00b1 2.2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">2.1 \u00b1 0.4</td></tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">A4</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1.02 \u00b1 0.02 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221215</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2.83 \u00b1 0.06 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221216</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2.33 \u00b1 0.02 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u221228</sup></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">3.7 \u00b1 1.1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">1.0 \u00b1 0.4</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong>\n<a name=\"apj404369t6fn1\" id=\"apj404369t6fn1\"></a><sup> a</sup>See Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s7\">7</a> for definitions of the various fluxes <em>f</em>(\u03bd). Fluxes quoted are measured values. <em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> is the lens magnification.</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t6_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/742/1/48\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t6_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>These rates are significantly smaller than those obtained for the 8 o'clock arc (Allam et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r1\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r1\">2007</a>) and the Clone (Lin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r46\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r46\">2009</a>), which were 229\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup> and 45\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, respectively (after converting to our chosen cosmology). Both of these systems were at much higher redshift (2.72 and 2.0, respectively) so one would potentially expect higher rates from these systems. They also had smaller values of <em>f</em><sub>lens</sub>. We can compare our result to blue galaxies at similar redshift from the DEEP2 survey (Cooper et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r20\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r20\">2008</a>). Using Figure 18 of Cooper et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r20\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r20\">2008</a>) we obtain a median SFR of about 34\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup> for a redshift <em>z</em> = 0.9 galaxy, which is also higher than our measurement. Other measurements using the AEGIS field (Noeske et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r57\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r57\">2007</a>) give a median SFR ranging from 10\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup> to 40\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup> depending weakly on the galaxy mass, which is unknown in our case. Our measurement can be compared to the far-right plot of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f1\">1</a> in Noeske et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r57\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r57\">2007</a>) and we fall on the low side of the measured data. Note that these conclusions are dependent on the magnification values used, for example, smaller values such as those obtained for the Clone or the 8 o'clock arc would yield larger values for the SFR.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj404369s8\" name=\"apj404369s8\">8.\u00a0CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We have reported on the discovery of a star-forming galaxy at a redshift of <em>z</em> = 0.9057 that is being strongly lensed by a massive galaxy cluster at a redshift of <em>z</em> = 0.3838.</p><p>The Einstein radius determined from the lensing features is \u03b8<sub>EIN</sub> = 7<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />53 \u00b1 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />25 and the enclosed mass is (1.5 \u00b1 0.1) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>13</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>, with a corresponding singular isothermal sphere velocity dispersion of \u03c3 = 694 \u00b1 12\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p>Using GMOS spectroscopic redshifts measured for 30 cluster member galaxies, we obtained a velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><em>c</em></sub> = 855<sup>+108</sup><sub>\u2212 96</sub>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> for the lensing cluster.</p><p>We have derived estimates of <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> from measurements of (1) weak lensing, (2) weak + strong lensing, (3) velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><em>c</em></sub>, and (4) cluster richness <em>N</em><sub>200</sub> = 55. We obtained the following results for <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>: (1) <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>(weak\u2009lensing) = 5.0<sup>+2.9</sup><sub>\u2212 2.3</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>, (2) <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>(lensing) = 4.9<sup>+2.9</sup><sub>\u2212 2.2</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>, (3) <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>(\u03c3<sub><em>c</em></sub>) = 5.79<sup>+2.22</sup><sub>\u2212 1.99</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> (assuming no velocity bias, <em>b<sub>v</sub></em> = 1), and (4) <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>(<em>N</em><sub>200</sub>) = (4.6 \u00b1 2.1) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>. These results are all very consistent with each other. The combination of the results from methods 2, 3, and 4 give <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> = 5.1<sup>+1.3</sup><sub>\u2212 1.3</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>, which is fully consistent with the individual measurements but with an error that is smaller by a factor of nearly two. The final NFW concentration from the combined fit is <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> = 5.4<sup>+1.4</sup><sub>\u2212 1.1</sub>, which is also consistent with the lensing-based value but again with a smaller error.</p><p>We have compared our measurements of <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> with predictions for (1) clusters from \u039bCDM simulations, (2) lensing-selected clusters from simulations, and (3) a real sample of cluster lenses from Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>). We find that we are most compatible with the predictions from \u039bCDM simulations for lensing clusters, and we see no evidence that an increased concentration is needed for this one system. We are studying this further using other lensing clusters we observed from the SDSS (Diehl et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r23\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r23\">2009</a>). These clusters will be the subject of a future paper.</p><p>Finally, we have estimated the SFR to be between 1.3 and 4.6 <em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, depending on magnification. These are small star-forming rates when compared to some of our previously reported systems, and are also small when compared with rates found for other galaxies at similar redshifts. However, we caution that this conclusion is entirely dependent on the derived lens magnification.</p></div><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We thank the anonymous reviewer for helpful comments which have improved the paper.</p><p>Based on observations obtained at the Gemini Observatory, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under a cooperative agreement with the NSF on behalf of the Gemini partnership: the National Science Foundation (United States), the Science and Technology Facilities Council (United Kingdom), the National Research Council (Canada), CONICYT (Chile), the Australian Research Council (Australia), Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia e Tecnologia (Brazil), and Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnolog\u00eda e Innovaci\u00f3n Productiva (Argentina). Gemini Proposal ID GS-2007B-Q-228.</p><p>The BCS was performed on the Blanco 4 m telescope located at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (National Optical Astronomy Observatory) which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, under contract with the National Science Foundation.</p><p>S.S.A. acknowledges support from an <em>HST</em> Grant. Support of program No. 11167 was provided by NASA through a grant from the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS5-26555.</p><p>A.Z. and J.J.M. acknowledge the support of the Excellence Cluster Universe in Garching. Support for M.B. was provided by the W. M. Keck Foundation.</p><p>Thanks go to Jeff Kubo for providing a copy of the Ellipto adaptive moments code. Thanks also go to Quarknet students Liana Nicklaus, Gina Castelvecchi, Braven Leung, Nick Gebbia, Alex Fitch, and their advisor Patrick Swanson, who worked with H.L. during summer 2009 on a weak lensing mass analysis of this cluster with different codes than used here.</p><p>Fermilab is operated by Fermi Research Alliance, LLC under Contract No. DE-AC02-07CH11359 with the United States Department of Energy.</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">THE SERENDIPITOUS OBSERVATION OF A GRAVITATIONALLY LENSED GALAXY AT <I>z</I> = 0.9057 FROM THE BLANCO COSMOLOGY SURVEY: THE ELLIOT ARC</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">E. Clicking this link will open your default email client.\" class=\"share-icon-link\">\n\t\t\t<img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/icon-email.svg\" alt=\"Share this content via class=\"da1 ta1\">\n                <!-- Start Linked Articles note -->\n\t<!-- End Linked Articles note -->\n<!-- Article information starts. This includes author emails, affiliations, article published date, doi etc. -->\n\t<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 wd-jnl-art-article-info-wrapper\">\n      \t<div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n        \t<a id=\"wd-article-info-accordion\" href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide article information\">Article information</a>\n      \t</div>\n      \t<div class=\"reveal-content\">\n        \t<div class=\"article-meta\">\n          \t\t<!-- Start Affiliations --><div class=\"wd-jnl-art-author-affiliations\"><div class=\"replica-h4\">Author affiliations</div><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>1</sup> Center for Particle Astrophysics, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, P.O. class=\"replica-h4\">Keywords</div>\n\t\t<p><a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F18&amp;code_desc=galaxies%3A+high-redshift\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=2%2F46&amp;code_desc=gravitational+lensing%3A+strong\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=2%2F47&amp;code_desc=gravitational+lensing%3A+weak\">gravitational lensing: weak</a></p>\n\t</div>\n<!-- Start Reprint Link -->\n\t<!--
