      <form id=\"alertsForm\" class=\"overlay-panel__form\" method=\"post\" action=\"\" role=\"form\" aria-labelledby=\"alerts-box-title\">\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__header\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n                        Receive alerts on all new research papers in American Astronomical Society\n                        (<span class=\"abbr__aas\">A&nbsp;A&nbsp;S&nbsp;</span>) journals as soon as they are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F742%2F1%2F48\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/742/1/48</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n                      <P>We report on the serendipitous discovery in the Blanco Cosmology Survey (BCS) imaging data of a <I>z</I> = 0.9057 galaxy that is being strongly lensed by a massive galaxy cluster at a redshift of <I>z</I> = 0.3838. The lens (BCS J2352\u20135452) was discovered while examining <I>i</I>- and <I>z</I>-band images being acquired in 2006 October during a BCS observing run. Follow-up spectroscopic observations with the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph instrument on the Gemini-South 8\u00a0m telescope confirmed the lensing nature of this system. Using weak-plus-strong lensing, velocity dispersion, cluster richness <I>N</I>             <SUB>200</SUB>, and fitting to a Navarro-Frenk-White (NFW) cluster mass density profile, we have made three independent estimates of the mass <I>M</I>             <SUB>200</SUB> which are all very consistent with each other. The combination of the results from the three methods gives <I>M</I>             <SUB>200</SUB> = (5.1 \u00b1 1.3) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<SUP>14</SUP> <I>M</I>             <SUB>\u2609</SUB>, which is fully consistent with the individual measurements. The final NFW concentration <I>c</I>             <SUB>200</SUB> from the combined fit is <I>c</I>             <SUB>200</SUB> = 5.4<SUP>+1.4</SUP>             <SUB>\u2013 1.1</SUB>. We have compared our measurements of <I>M</I>             <SUB>200</SUB> and <I>c</I>             <SUB>200</SUB> with predictions for (1) clusters from \u039bCDM simulations, (2) lensing-selected clusters from simulations, and (3) a real sample of cluster lenses. We find that we are most compatible with the predictions for \u039bCDM simulations for lensing clusters, and we see no evidence based on this one system for an increased concentration compared to \u039bCDM. Finally, using the flux measured from the [O <span class=\"small-caps\">II</span>]3727 line we have determined the star formation rate of the source galaxy and find it to be rather modest given the assumed lens magnification.</P>       </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/742/1/48&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/742/1/48&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/742/1/48&doi=10.1088/0004-637X/742/1/48&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2011ApJ...742...48B\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2011ApJ...742...48B&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2011ApJ...742...48B\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj404369s1\" name=\"apj404369s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Strong gravitational lenses offer unique opportunities to study cosmology, dark matter, galactic structure, and galaxy evolution. They also provide a sample of galaxies, namely the lenses themselves, that are selected based on total mass rather than luminosity or surface brightness. The majority of lenses discovered in the past decade were found through dedicated surveys using a variety of techniques. For example, the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) data have been used to effectively select lens candidates from rich clusters (Hennawi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r29\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r29\">2008</a>) through intermediate-scale clusters (Allam et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r1\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r1\">2007</a>; Lin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r46\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r46\">2009</a>) to individual galaxies (Bolton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r10\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r10\">2008</a>; Willis et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r71\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r71\">2006</a>). Other searches using the CFHTLS (Cabanac et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r16\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r16\">2007</a>) and COSMOS fields (Faure et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r26\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r26\">2008</a>; Jackson <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r35\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r35\">2008</a>) have yielded 40 and 70 lens candidates, respectively. These searches cover the range of giant arcs with Einstein radii \u03b8<sub>EIN</sub> &gt; 10'' all the way to small arcs produced by single lens galaxies with \u03b8<sub>EIN</sub> &lt; 3''.</p><p>In this paper, we report on the serendipitous discovery of a strongly lensed <em>z</em> = 0.9057 galaxy in the Blanco Cosmology Survey (BCS) imaging data. The lens is a rich cluster containing a prominent central brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) and has a redshift of <em>z</em> = 0.3838. Cluster-scale lenses are particularly useful as they allow us to study the effects of strong lensing in the core of the cluster and weak lensing in the outer regions. Strong lensing provides constraints on the mass contained within the Einstein radius of the arcs, whereas weak lensing provides information on the mass profiles in the outer reaches of the cluster. Combining the two measurements allows us to make tighter constraints on the mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and the concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>, of a Navarro\u2013Frenk\u2013White (NFW; Navarro et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r55\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r55\">1995</a>) model of the cluster mass density profile, over a wider range of radii than would be possible with either method alone (Natarajan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r54\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r54\">1998</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r53\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r53\">2002</a>; Bradac\u02d8 et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r12\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r12\">2006</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r11\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r11\">2008a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r13\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r13\">2008b</a>; Diego et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r22\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r22\">2007</a>; Limousin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r45\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r45\">2007</a>; Hicks et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r30\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r30\">2007</a>; Deb et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r21\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r21\">2008</a>; Merten et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r50\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r50\">2009</a>; Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>). In addition, if one has spectroscopic redshifts for the member galaxies one can determine the cluster velocity dispersion, assuming that the cluster is virialized, and hence obtain an independent estimate for <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> (Becker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r4\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r4\">2007</a>). Finally, one can also derive an <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> estimate from the maxBCG cluster richness <em>N</em><sub>200</sub> (Hansen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r28\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r28\">2005</a>; Johnston et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r36\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r36\">2007</a>). These three different methods, strong plus weak lensing, cluster velocity dispersion, and optical richness, provide independent estimates of <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> (<em>M</em><sub>200</sub> is defined as the mass within a sphere of overdensity 200 times the critical density at the redshift <em>z</em>) and can then be combined to obtain improved constraints on <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>. Measurements of the concentration from strong lensing clusters is of particular interest as recent publications suggest that they may be more concentrated than one would expect from \u039bCDM models (Broadhurst &amp; Barkana <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r14\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r14\">2008</a>; Oguri &amp; Blandford <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r58\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r58\">2009</a>).</p><p>This paper is organized as follows. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s2\">2</a> we describe the BCS. Then in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3\">3</a> we discuss the initial discovery and the spectroscopic follow-up that led to confirmation of the system as a gravitational lens, the data reduction, the properties of the cluster, the extraction of the redshifts, and finally the measurement of the cluster velocity dispersion and estimate of the cluster mass. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s4\">4</a> we summarize the strong lensing features of the system. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s5\">5</a> we describe the weak lensing measurements. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6\">6</a> we present the results of combining the strong and weak lensing, and the final mass constraints derived from combining the lensing results with the velocity dispersion and richness measurements. We describe the source galaxy star formation rate (SFR) measurements in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s7\">7</a>, and finally in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s8\">8</a> we conclude. We assume a flat cosmology with \u03a9<sub>M</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7, and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, unless otherwise noted.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj404369s2\" name=\"apj404369s2\">2.\u00a0THE BCS SURVEY</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The BCS is a 60 night NOAO imaging survey program (2005\u20132008), using the Mosaic-II camera on the Blanco 4\u00a0m telescope at CTIO, which has uniformly imaged <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn1.gif\" alt=\"$75 \\deg ^2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">75 \\deg ^2</script></span></span> of the sky in the SDSS <em>griz</em> bands in preparation for cluster finding with the South Pole Telescope (SPT; Vanderlinde et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r70\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r70\">2010</a>) and other millimeter-wave experiments. The depths in each band were chosen to allow the estimation of photometric redshifts for <em>L</em> &#x2265; <em>L</em><sub>*</sub> galaxies out to a redshift of <em>z</em> = 1 and to detect galaxies to 0.5<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> at 5\u03c3 to these same redshifts. The survey was divided into two fields to allow efficient use of the allotted nights between October and December. Both fields lie near \u03b4 = \u221255\u00b0, which allows for overlap with the SPT. One field is centered near \u03b1 = 23.5\u00a0hr and the other is at \u03b1 = 5.5\u00a0hr. In addition to the large science fields, BCS also covers seven small fields that overlap large spectroscopic surveys so that photometric redshifts (photo-<em>z</em>'s) using BCS data can be trained and tested using a sample of over 5000 galaxies.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj404369s3\" name=\"apj404369s3\">3.\u00a0DISCOVERY OF THE LENS AND SPECTROSCOPIC FOLLOW-UP</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The lens BCS J2351\u22125452 was discovered serendipitously while examining <em>i</em>- and <em>z</em>-band images being acquired in 2006 October during the yearly BCS observing run. The discoverer (E.J.B.-G.) decided to name it \"The Elliot Arc\" in honor of her then-eight-year-old nephew. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t1\">1</a> lists the observed images along with seeing conditions. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f1\">1</a> shows a <em>gri</em> color image of the source, lens, and surrounding environment (the pixel scale is 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />268\u00a0per\u00a0pixel). The source forms a purple ring-like structure of radius ~7<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 with multiple distinct bright regions. The lens is the BCG at the center of a large galaxy cluster. Photometric measurements estimated the redshift of the cluster at <em>z</em> ~ 0.4, using the expected <em>g</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>r</em> and <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> red sequence colors, and also provided a photo-<em>z</em> for the source of <em>z</em> ~ 0.7, as described below. We note that this cluster was first reported as SCSO J235138-545253 in an independent analysis of the BCS data by Menanteau et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r50a\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r50a\">2010</a>) where its remarkable lens was noted and they estimated a photometric redshift of <em>z</em> = 0.33 for the cluster.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0<em>gri</em> color image of the Elliot Arc and its cluster environment. The scale is indicated by the horizontal arrow.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj404369t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0Observation EG21</td></tr></tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/742/1/48\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>We obtained Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph (GMOS) spectra of the source and a number of neighboring galaxies (Lin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r47\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r47\">2007</a>). We targeted the regions of the source labeled A1\u2013A4 in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f2\">2</a>, and photometric properties of these bright knots are summarized in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t2\">2</a>. In addition, we selected 51 more objects for a total of 55 spectra. The additional objects were selected using their colors in order to pick out likely cluster member galaxies. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f3\">3</a> shows the <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> versus <em>i</em> color\u2013magnitude diagram (top plot) and the <em>g</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>r</em> versus <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> color\u2013color diagram (bottom plot) of the field. The blue squares in the bottom panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f3\">3</a> show the four targeted knots in the lensed arcs. The green curve is an Scd galaxy model (Coleman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r19\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r19\">1980</a>) with the green circles indicating a photometric redshift for the arc of <em>z</em> ~ 0.7. Note that this is not a detailed photo-<em>z</em> fit, but is just a rough estimate meant to show that the arc is likely at a redshift higher than the cluster redshift. The highest target priority was given to the arc knots and to the BCG. Then cluster red sequence galaxy targets were selected using the simple color cuts 1.55 &#x2264; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &#x2264; 1.9 and 0.6 &#x2264; <em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &#x2264; 0.73 (also shown in the bottom panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f3\">3</a>), which approximate the more detailed final cluster membership criteria described below in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-2\">3.2</a>. Red sequence galaxies with <em>i</em> &lt; 21.6 (3'' diameter SExtractor aperture magnitudes) were selected, with higher priority given to brighter galaxies with <em>i</em>(3'') &#x2264; 21. Additional non-cluster targets lying outside the cluster color selection box were added at lowest priority.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0<em>gri</em> color image of the Elliot Arc. The knots targeted for spectroscopy are shown as green circles. The scale is indicated by the horizontal line.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Top: <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> vs. <em>i</em>(<tt>MAG_AUTO</tt>) color\u2013magnitude diagram for all galaxies (black points) with <em>i</em> &lt; 21 and within a radius <em>r</em><sup>gal</sup><sub>200</sub> = 1.51\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc (=6<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcm.gif\" alt=\"farcm\" align=\"baseline\" />88) of the BCG. Colors are measured using 3'' diameter aperture magnitudes. Galaxies meeting the maxBCG cluster color selection criteria (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-2\">3.2</a>) are plotted in red, with red circles indicating cluster members brighter than <em>i</em> = 20.5, and red squares indicating fainter cluster members. Bottom: <em>g</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>r</em> vs. <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> color\u2013color diagram for the same galaxies as in the top panel. Red circles and squares again indicate brighter and fainter maxBCG cluster members, while the black rectangle indicates the color selection box (approximating the more detailed maxBCG color criteria) used to select likely cluster galaxies for GMOS spectroscopy (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3\">3</a>). In addition, the four bright knots A1\u2013A4 (Figure <a href=\"#apj404369f2\">2</a>) in the lensed arcs are shown by the blue squares. The green curve is an Scd galaxy model (Coleman et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r19\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r19\">1980</a>) at redshifts <em>z</em> = 0\u20132, with green circles highlighting the redshift range <em>z</em> = 0.65\u20130.75, indicating an approximate photometric redshift <em>z</em> ~ 0.7 for the arc knots.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f3\" id=\"apj404369t2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 2.</b>\u00a0Knots Targeted for Spectroscopy</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369t2\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t2_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 2\"><colgroup><col rowspan=\"1\">0.77</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong>\n<a name=\"apj404369t2fn1\" id=\"apj404369t2fn1\"></a><sup> a</sup>R.A. and decl. are epoch J2000.0 and are given in degrees.\n<a name=\"apj404369t2fn2\" id=\"apj404369t2fn2\"></a><sup> b</sup><em>i</em>-band magnitudes for the knots are computed in 3'' diameter apertures, after first subtracting a model of the BCG light derived using the GALFIT galaxy fitting program (Peng et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r61\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r61\">2002</a>).\n<a name=\"apj404369t2fn3\" id=\"apj404369t2fn3\"></a><sup> c</sup><em>g</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>r</em> and <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> colors are computed from 3'' diameter SExtractor aperture magnitudes.</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t2_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/742/1/48\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t2_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>We used the GMOS R150 grating + the GG455 filter in order to obtain spectra with about 4600\u20139000\u2009\u00c5 wavelength coverage. This was designed to cover the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 3727 emission line expected at ~6300\u2009\u00c5, given the photo-<em>z</em> estimate of ~0.7 for the arcs as well as the Mg absorption features at ~7000\u2009\u00c5 (and the 4000\u2009\u00c5 break at ~5600\u2009\u00c5) for the <em>z</em> ~ 0.4 cluster elliptical galaxies.</p><p>We used two MOS masks in order to fully target these cluster galaxies (along with the arcs) for spectroscopy. Each mask had a 3600 s exposure time split into four 900\u00a0s exposures for cosmic ray removal. We also took standard Cu\u2013Ar lamp spectra for wavelength calibrations and standard star spectra for flux calibrations. All data were taken in a queue observing mode. A summary of the observations is given in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t1\">1</a>.</p><h3 id=\"apj404369s3-1\" name=\"apj404369s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Data Reduction</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The BCS imaging data were processed using the Dark Energy Survey data management system (DESDM V3), which is under development at UIUC/NCSA/Fermilab (Mohr et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r51\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r51\">2008</a>; Ngeow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r56\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r56\">2006</a>; Zenteno et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r73\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r73\">2011</a>). The images are corrected for instrumental effects, which include crosstalk correction, pupil ghost correction, overscan correction, trimming, bias subtraction, flat fielding, and illumination correction. The images are then astrometrically calibrated and remapped for later coaddition. For photometric data, a photometric calibration is applied to the single-epoch and coadd object photometry. The Astr<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn2.gif\" alt=\"$\\cal O$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\cal O</script></span></span>matic software<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj404369fn1\">21</a></sup> SExtractor (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r8\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r8\">1996</a>), SCAMP (Bertin <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r7\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r7\">2006</a>), and SWarp (Bertin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r9\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r9\">2002</a>) are used for cataloging, astrometric refinement, and remapping for coaddition over each image. We have used the coadded images in the <em>griz</em> bands for this analysis.</p><p>The spectroscopic data were processed using the standard data reduction package provided by Gemini that runs in the IRAF framework.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj404369fn2\">22</a></sup> We used version 1.9.1. This produced flux- and wavelength-calibrated one-dimensional spectra for all the objects. Additional processing for the source spectra was done using the IRAF task <tt>apall</tt>.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj404369s3-2\" name=\"apj404369s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Cluster Properties</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We adopt the procedure used by the maxBCG cluster finder (Koester et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r40\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r40\">2007a</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r41\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r41\">2007b</a>) to determine cluster membership and cluster richness and to derive a richness-based cluster mass estimate. We first measure <em>N</em><sub>gal</sub>, the number of cluster red sequence galaxies, within a radius 1\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc (=4<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcm.gif\" alt=\"farcm\" align=\"baseline\" />55) of the BCG, which are also brighter than 0.4<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> at the cluster redshift <em>z</em> = 0.38. From Koester et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r40\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r40\">2007a</a>), 0.4<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> corresponds to an <em>i</em>-band absolute magnitude <em>M</em> = \u221220.25 + 5log\u2009<em>h</em> at <em>z</em> = 0, while at <em>z</em> = 0.38, 0.4<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> corresponds to an apparent magnitude <em>i</em> = 20.5 (specific value provided by J. Annis &amp; J. Kubo 2007, private communication), after accounting for both <em>K</em>-correction and evolution (also as described in Koester et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r40\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r40\">2007a</a>). We apply this magnitude cut using the SExtractor <em>i</em>-band <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt> magnitude, which provides a measure of a galaxy's total light. (Note the 3'' diameter aperture magnitude used earlier for target selection in general measures less light compared to <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt>, but is better suited for roughly approximating the light entering a GMOS slit.) We set the red sequence membership cuts to be <em>g</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>r</em> and <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> color both within 2\u03c3 of their respective central values (<em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em>)<sub>0</sub> = 1.77 and (<em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em>)<sub>0</sub> = 0.65, where the latter are determined empirically based on the peaks of the color histograms of galaxies within 1\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc of the BCG. In applying the color cuts we use the colors defined by SExtractor 3'' diameter aperture magnitudes (this provides higher signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) colors compared to using <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt>), and for the uncertainty we define <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn3.gif\" alt=\"$\\sigma = \\sqrt{\\vphantom{A^A}\\smash{\\hbox{${\\sigma _{{\\rm color}}^2 + \\sigma _{{\\rm intrinsic}}^2}$}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sigma = \\sqrt{\\vphantom{A^A}\\smash{\\hbox{${\\sigma _{{\\rm color}}^2 + \\sigma _{{\\rm intrinsic}}^2}$}}}</script></span></span>, where \u03c3<sub>color</sub> is the color measurement error derived from the SExtractor aperture magnitude errors and \u03c3<sub>intrinsic</sub> is the intrinsic red sequence color width, taken to be 0.05 for <em>g</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>r</em> and 0.06 for <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> (Koester et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r40\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r40\">2007a</a>).</p><p>Carrying out the above magnitude and color cuts, we obtain an initial richness estimate <em>N</em><sub>gal</sub> = 44. Then, as discussed in Hansen et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r28\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r28\">2005</a>), we define another radius <em>r</em><sup>gal</sup><sub>200</sub> = 0.156<em>N</em><sub>gal</sub><sup>0.6</sup>\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc = 1.51\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc (=6<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcm.gif\" alt=\"farcm\" align=\"baseline\" />88), and repeat the same cuts within <em>r</em><sup>gal</sup><sub>200</sub> of the BCG to obtain a final richness estimate <em>N</em><sub>200</sub> = 55. Finally, using the weak lensing mass calibration of Johnston et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r36\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r36\">2007</a>) for maxBCG clusters, we obtain a mass estimate <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> = (8.794 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>13</sup>) <b>&#x00d7;</b> (<em>N</em><sub>200</sub>/20)<sup>1.28</sup>\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> = (4.6 \u00b1 2.1) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>\u2009(<em>h</em> = 0.7), where we have also adopted the fractional error of 0.45 derived by Rozo et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r65\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r65\">2009</a>) for this <em>N</em><sub>200</sub>-based estimate of <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> for maxBCG clusters.</p><p>We note that Rozo et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r66\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r66\">2010</a>) apply a factor of 1.18 to correct the Johnston et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r36\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r36\">2007</a>) cluster masses upward, in order to account for a photo-<em>z</em> bias effect that is detailed in Mandelbaum et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r48\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r48\">2008</a>). We have not applied this correction as it makes only a 0.4\u03c3 difference, although we remark that the resulting mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> = 5.4 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> does appear to improve the (already good) agreement with our other mass estimates below (see Sections <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-4\">3.4</a> and\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-1\">6.1</a>).</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f3\">3</a> shows color\u2013magnitude and color\u2013color plots of all galaxies that have <em>i</em> &lt; 21 (SExtractor <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt>) and that are within a radius <em>r</em><sup>gal</sup><sub>200</sub> = 1.51\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc (=6<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcm.gif\" alt=\"farcm\" align=\"baseline\" />88) of the BCG. Note that we have extended the magnitude limit here down to <em>i</em> = 21, to match the effective magnitude limit of our spectroscopic redshift sample (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-3\">3.3</a>). In particular, we find 86 maxBCG cluster members for <em>i</em> &lt; 21, compared to the earlier <em>N</em><sub>200</sub> = 55 for <em>i</em> &lt; 20.5 (corresponding to 0.4<em>L</em><sub>*</sub>). These member galaxies are shown using red symbols in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f3\">3</a> and their properties are given in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t3\">3</a>.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj404369t3\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 3.</b>\u00a0Cluster Galaxies</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369t3\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t3_lr.gif\" valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">11813</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">357.856326</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">\u221254.957697</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">19.40 \u00b1 0.01</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">1.70 \u00b1 0.03</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">0.63 valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">14505</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">357.870029</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">\u221254.888283</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" \u00b1 0.03</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"pm\">0.3860 \u00b1 0.0003</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small>\n<strong>Notes.</strong>\n<a name=\"apj404369t3fn1\" id=\"apj404369t3fn1\"></a><sup> a</sup>Object ID numbers are from the SExtractor catalog obtained using the <em>i</em>-band image for object detection. The objects are ordered from bright to faint by <em>i</em>-band <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt>, starting with the BCG. <em>g</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>r</em> and <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> colors are computed from 3'' diameter aperture magnitudes. The errors are simply statistical errors reported by SExtractor. Not included are photometric calibration errors estimated to be 0.03\u20130.05\u00a0mag per filter.\n<a name=\"apj404369t3fn2\" id=\"apj404369t3fn2\"></a><sup> b</sup>R.A. and decl. are epoch J2000.0 and are given in degrees.\n<a name=\"apj404369t3fn3\" id=\"apj404369t3fn3\"></a><sup> c</sup>Redshifts measured from GMOS spectroscopy (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-3\">3.3</a>).\n<a name=\"apj404369t3fn4\" id=\"apj404369t3fn4\"></a><sup> d</sup>Galaxies, with <em>i</em> &lt; 21, determined to be cluster members using maxBCG color selection criteria. Members are also limited to be within a radius <em>r</em><sup>gal</sup><sub>200</sub> = 1.51\u2009<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc (=6<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcm.gif\" alt=\"farcm\" align=\"baseline\" />88) of the BCG. See Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-2\">3.2</a> for details.\n<a name=\"apj404369t3fn5\" id=\"apj404369t3fn5\"></a><sup> e</sup>Additional galaxies determined to be cluster members via GMOS spectroscopic redshifts (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-3\">3.3</a>), but which did not meet the maxBCG color selection criteria.</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t3_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/742/1/48\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a>Typeset images: <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t3_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">1</a> <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t3a_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">2</a> </span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apj404369s3-3\" name=\"apj404369s3-3\">3.3.\u00a0Redshift Determinations</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The redshift extraction was carried out using the <tt>xcsao</tt> and <tt>emsao</tt> routines in the IRAF external package <tt>rvsao</tt> (Kurtz &amp; Mink <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r44\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r44\">1998</a>). We obtained spectra for the 55 objects that were targeted. Four of these spectra were of the source. Out of the remaining 51 spectra we had sufficient S/N in 42 of them to determine a redshift. Thirty of the objects with redshifts between 0.377 and 0.393 constitute our spectroscopic sample of cluster galaxies. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f4\">4</a> shows the spatial distribution of galaxies within a 6' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 6' box centered on the BCG, with maxBCG cluster members, arc knots, and objects with spectroscopic redshifts indicated by different colors and symbols. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t3\">3</a> summarizes the properties of the 30 cluster member galaxies with redshifts, and Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t4\">4</a> summarizes the properties of the remaining 12 spectroscopic non-member galaxies. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f5\">5</a>, we show four examples of the flux-calibrated cluster member spectra including the BCG.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Relative positions of all galaxies (points) with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn6.gif\" alt=\"$i({\\rm \\tt MAG\\_AUTO}) &lt; 21$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">i({\\rm \\tt MAG\\_AUTO}) < 21</script></span></span> within a 6' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 6' box centered on the BCG. Cluster member galaxies defined using maxBCG criteria (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-2\">3.2</a>) are plotted in red, with red circles indicating members brighter than <em>i</em> = 20.5, and red squares indicating fainter members. The four bright knots A1\u2013A4 (Figure <a href=\"#apj404369f2\">2</a>) in the lensed arcs are shown by the blue squares. Galaxies determined to be cluster members from GMOS redshifts are plotted with open magenta circles, while those found spectroscopically to be non-members are shown with open cyan triangles (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-3\">3.3</a>). North is up and east is to the left.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden;
