members based on GMOS spectroscopic redshifts (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-3\">3.3</a>).\n<a name=\"apj404369t4fn2\" id=\"apj404369t4fn2\"></a><sup> b</sup>Object ID numbers are from the SExtractor catalog obtained using the <em>i</em>-band image for object detection. The objects are ordered from bright to faint by <em>i</em>-band <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt>. <em>g</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>r</em> and <em>r</em>\u2009\u2212\u2009<em>i</em> colors are computed from 3'' diameter aperture magnitudes. The errors are simply statistical errors reported by SExtractor. Not included are photometric calibration errors estimated to be 0.03\u20130.05\u00a0mag per filter.\n<a name=\"apj404369t4fn3\" id=\"apj404369t4fn3\"></a><sup> c</sup>R.A. and decl. are epoch J2000.0 and are given in degrees.\n<a name=\"apj404369t4fn4\" id=\"apj404369t4fn4\"></a><sup> d</sup>Redshifts measured from GMOS spectroscopy (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-3\">3.3</a>).</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n            Download table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t4_ascii.txt?doi=10.1088/0004-637X/742/1/48\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/suppdata/apj404369t4_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Examination of Tables <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t3\">3</a> and\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t4\">4</a> shows that our spectroscopic sample is effectively limited at <em>i</em> \u2248 21, as 39 of the 42 non-arc redshifts have <em>i</em> &lt; 21. Note that of the 30 spectroscopically defined cluster members, 22 are also maxBCG members, while another 7 lie close to the maxBCG color selection boundaries. Also, of the 12 spectroscopic non-members, none meet the maxBCG criteria except the faintest one (with <em>i</em> = 21.58).</p><p>The redshift of the source was determined from a single emission line at 7100\u2009\u00c5, which is present with varying S/N in each of the knots that were observed. We take this line to be the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]3727\u2009\u00c5 line which yields a redshift of 0.9057\u2009 \u00b1 \u20090.0005. The four flux-calibrated source spectra are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f6\">6</a>. Knot A2 was observed under seeing conditions that were a factor of two worse than for the other three knots (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t1\">1</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Flux-calibrated spectra (in <em>f</em><sub>\u03bd</sub>) for the knots A1\u2013A4. The spectra have been smoothed (with a boxcar of 5 pixels = 17.8\u2009\u00c5) to improve S/N. Knot A2 was observed under seeing conditions that were a factor of two worse than for the other three knots. The [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 3727\u2009\u00c5 line is marked.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apj404369s3-4\" name=\"apj404369s3-4\">3.4.\u00a0Velocity Dispersion and Cluster Mass Measurement</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We used the 30 cluster galaxies to estimate the redshift and velocity dispersion of the cluster using the biweight estimators of Beers et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r5\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r5\">1990</a>). We first use the biweight location estimator to determine the best estimate for <em>cz</em>. This yields a value of <em>cz</em> = 115151.1 \u00b1 241.1\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, which translates to a redshift of <em>z<sub>c</sub></em> = 0.3838 \u00b1 0.0008. We then use this estimate of the cluster redshift to determine the peculiar velocity <em>v<sub>p</sub></em> for each cluster member relative to the cluster center of mass using\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} v_p = \\frac{(cz - cz_c)}{(1+z_c)}. \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>We determine the biweight estimate of scale for <em>v<sub>p</sub></em> which is equal to the velocity dispersion of the cluster. We find a value for the velocity dispersion of \u03c3<sub><em>c</em></sub> = 855<sup>+108</sup><sub>\u2212 96</sub>\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The uncertainties are obtained by performing a jackknife resampling. The redshift distribution is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f7\">7</a>. The overlaid Gaussian has a mean of <em>z<sub>c</sub></em> and a width of \u03c3<sub><em>c</em></sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> (1 + <em>z<sub>c</sub></em>). The lines represent the individual peculiar velocities <em>v<sub>p</sub></em> of the cluster members.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0Redshift distribution for the 30 cluster members in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t3\">3</a>. The tick marks at the top represent the individual cluster member peculiar velocities. The solid line is a Gaussian with mean and sigma equal to <em>z<sub>c</sub></em> and \u03c3<sub><em>c</em></sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> (1 + <em>z<sub>c</sub></em>), respectively (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-4\">3.4</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We can use the estimated velocity dispersion to derive an estimate for the cluster mass. We use the results of Evrard et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r25\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r25\">2008</a>; see also Becker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r4\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r4\">2007</a>), which relate <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> to the dark matter velocity dispersion\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} M_{200} = 10^{15}\\, M_{\\odot } \\frac{1}{h(z)} \\left(\\frac{\\sigma _{{\\rm DM}}}{\\sigma _{15}} \\right) ^{1/\\alpha }, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>h</em>(<em>z</em>) = <em>H</em>(<em>z</em>)/100\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup> is the dimensionless Hubble parameter. The values of the parameters were found to be \u03c3<sub>15</sub> = 1082.9 \u00b1 4\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and \u03b1 = 0.3361 \u00b1 0.0026 (Evrard et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r25\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r25\">2008</a>). Using the standard definition of velocity bias <em>b<sub>v</sub></em> = \u03c3<sub>gal</sub>/\u03c3<sub>DM</sub>, where \u03c3<sub>gal</sub> is the galaxy cluster velocity dispersion, we can rewrite Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd2\">2</a>) as\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd3.gif\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} b_v^{1/\\alpha }\\, M_{200} = 10^{15}\\ M_{\\odot } \\frac{1}{h(z)} \\left(\\frac{\\sigma _{{\\rm gal}}}{\\sigma _{15}}\\right) ^{1/\\alpha }, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where the quantity <em>b</em><sup>1/\u03b1</sup><sub><em>v</em></sub><em>M</em><sub>200</sub> parameterizes our lack of knowledge about velocity bias. Substituting in the measured values for \u03c3<sub>gal</sub> we obtain <em>b</em><sup>1/\u03b1</sup><sub><em>v</em></sub><em>M</em><sub>200</sub> = 5.79<sup>+2.22</sup><sub>\u2212 1.99</sub> <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>.</p><p>Bayliss et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r3\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r3\">2011</a> and references therein) discuss an \"orientation bias\" effect which causes an upward bias in the measured velocity dispersions of lensing-selected clusters, due to the higher likelihood of the alignment along the line of sight of the major axes of the cluster halos, which are in general triaxial. Bayliss et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r3\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r3\">2011</a>) estimate that on average this will result in the dynamical mass estimate being biased high by 19%\u201320%, using the same relation between <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and velocity dispersion as we have used (Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd2\">2</a>) above; Evrard et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r25\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r25\">2008</a>). Correcting for this orientation bias effect would result in <em>b</em><sup>1/\u03b1</sup><sub><em>v</em></sub><em>M</em><sub>200</sub> = 4.8 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>14</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>, which is not a significant difference, as the change is well under 1\u03c3. We therefore do not apply this correction, but we do note that it would improve the already good agreement with our other mass estimates in Sections <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s3-2\">3.2</a> and\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-1\">6.1</a> (assuming no velocity bias, <em>b<sub>v</sub></em> = 1).</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj404369s4\" name=\"apj404369s4\">4.\u00a0STRONG LENSING PROPERTIES</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We use the coadded <em>r</em>-band image shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f8\">8</a> to study the strong lensing features of the system as it has the best seeing and hence shows the most detail. To remove the contribution to the arc fluxes from nearby objects we used GALFIT (Peng et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r61\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r61\">2002</a>) to model the profiles of these objects (galaxies and stars) and then subtracted the model from the image. This was done for all four <em>griz</em> bands. These subtracted images are used for all determinations of arc fluxes and positions. A number of individual knots can be observed in the system along with the more elongated features. For example, it appears that knot A1 is actually composed of two individual bright regions which are resolved by the SExtractor object extraction described below. Knot A2 also appears to have two components although these are not resolved by the object extraction so we treat them as one in the modeling. Even though the cluster is fairly massive we do not see evidence for additional arc-like features outside of the central circular feature. In this case, we expect the mass of the lens to be well constrained by the image positions.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Coadded <em>r</em>-band image. The lensing features can be clearly seen.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We use the criteria that to obtain multiple images the average surface mass density within the tangential critical curve must equal the critical surface mass density \u03a3<sub>crit</sub>. The tangentially oriented arcs occur at approximately the tangential critical curves and so the radius of the circle \u03b8<sub>arc</sub> traced by the arcs provides a measurement of the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>EIN</sub> (Narayan &amp; Bartelmann <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r52\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r52\">1996</a>). The mass <em>M</em><sub>EIN</sub> enclosed with the Einstein radius is therefore given by\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd4\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd4.gif\" alt=\"Equation (4)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} M_{{\\rm EIN}} = \\Sigma _{{\\rm crit}}\\pi (D_l \\theta _{{\\rm EIN}})^{2}. \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t4\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Substituting for \u03a3<sub>crit</sub> gives\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd5\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd5.gif\" alt=\"Equation (5)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} M_{{\\rm EIN}} = \\frac{c^2}{4G} \\frac{D_l D_s}{D_{{\\rm ls}}}\\theta ^2_{{\\rm EIN}}, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t5\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>D<sub>s</sub></em> is the angular diameter distance to the source, <em>D<sub>l</sub></em> is the angular diameter distance to the lens, and <em>D</em><sub>ls</sub> is the angular diameter distance between the lens and the source. These values are <em>D<sub>s</sub></em> = 1610\u00a0Mpc, <em>D<sub>l</sub></em> = 1081\u00a0Mpc, and <em>D</em><sub>ls</sub> = 825\u00a0Mpc.</p><p>To determine the Einstein radius, we ran SExtractor (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r8\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r8\">1996</a>) on the <em>r</em>-band image. This identified eight distinct objects in the image. We used the coordinates of those eight objects and fit them to a circle. The radius of the circle gives us a measure of the Einstein radius. The Einstein radius we measure is \u03b8<sub>EIN</sub> = 7<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />53\u2009 \u00b1 \u20090<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />25 which translates to 39.5\u2009 \u00b1 \u20091.3\u00a0kpc. This yields a mass estimate of (1.5\u2009 \u00b1 \u20090.1)\u2009 <b>&#x00d7;</b> \u200910<sup>13</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub> and a corresponding velocity dispersion (assuming an isothermal model for the mass distribution) of \u03c3 = 694 \u00b1 12\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p>The magnification of the lens <em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> can be roughly estimated under the assumption that the half-light radius of a source at redshift <em>z</em> ~ 0.9 is about 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />46 (derived from the mock galaxy catalog described in Jouvel et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r37\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r37\">2009</a>). The ratio of the area subtended by the ring to that subtended by the source is ~0.6 <b>&#x00d7;</b> (4<em>R</em>/\u03b4<em>r</em>), where <em>R</em> is the ring radius and \u03b4<em>r</em> is the half-light radius of the source. The 0.6 factor accounts for the fraction of the ring that actually contains images. This gives a magnification of <em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> = 39.</p><p>To obtain a more quantitative value for the magnification we have used the <tt>PixeLens</tt><sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apj404369fn3\">23</a></sup> program (Saha &amp; Williams <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r67\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r67\">2004</a>) to model the lens. <tt>PixeLens</tt> is a parametric modeling program that reconstructs a pixelated mass map of the lens. It uses as input the coordinates of the extracted image positions and their parities along with the lens and source redshifts. It samples the solution space using a Markov Chain Monte Carlo method and generates an ensemble of mass models that reproduce the image positions. We used the SExtractor image positions obtained above and assigned the parities according to the prescription given in Read (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r63\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r63\">2007</a>). In Saha &amp; Williams (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r67\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r67\">2004</a>) they note that if one uses pixels that are too large then the mass distribution is poorly resolved and not enough steep mass models are allowed. We have chosen a pixel size such that this should not be a problem.</p><p>It is well known (see, for example, Saha &amp; Williams <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r68\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r68\">2006</a>) that changing the slope of the mass profile changes the overall magnification, in particular a steeper slope produces a smaller magnification but does not change the image positions. Therefore, the quoted magnification should be taken as a representative example rather than a definitive answer. The magnification quoted is the sum over the average values of the magnification for each image position for 100 models. We obtain a value of <em>f</em><sub>lens</sub> = 141 \u00b1 39 where the error is the quadrature sum of the rms spreads of the individual image magnifications. <tt>PixeLens</tt> can also determine the enclosed mass within a given radius. For the 100 models we obtain <em>M</em><sub>EIN</sub> = (1.4 \u00b1 0.02) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>13</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>, which is within 1\u03c3 of the mass obtained from the circle fit described above.</p><p>In order to combine the strong lensing mass with the mass estimate from the weak lensing analysis (in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s6-1\">6.1</a> below), we will need to estimate the mass within \u03b8<sub>EIN</sub> that is due to dark matter alone (<em>M</em><sub>DM</sub>). To do this we will need to subtract estimates of the stellar mass (<em>M<sub>S</sub></em>) and the hot gas mass (<em>M<sub>G</sub></em>) from the total mass <em>M</em><sub>EIN</sub>. To determine <em>M<sub>S</sub></em> we use the GALAXEV (Bruzual &amp; Charlot <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r15\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r15\">2003</a>) evolutionary stellar population synthesis code to fit galaxy spectral energy distribution models to the <em>griz</em> magnitudes of the BCG within the Einstein radius. The BCG photometric data are taken from the GALFIT modeling described above, and we sum up the light of the point-spread function (PSF)-deconvolved GALFIT model inside the Einstein radius. The GALAXEV models considered are simple stellar population (SSP) models which have an initial, instantaneous burst of star formation; such models provide good fits to early-type galaxies, such as those in clusters. In particular we find a good fit to the BCG, using an SSP model with solar metallicity, a Chabrier (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r17\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r17\">2003</a>) stellar initial mass function (IMF), and an age 9.25 Gyr (this age provided the best \u03c7<sup>2</sup> over the range we considered, from 1 Gyr to 9.3 Gyr, the latter being the age of the universe for our cosmology at the cluster redshift <em>z</em> = 0.38). The resulting stellar mass (more precisely the total stellar mass integrated over the IMF) is <em>M<sub>S</sub></em> = 1.7 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>12</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>.</p><p>To estimate the gas mass <em>M<sub>G</sub></em>, we have looked at estimates of hot gas fraction <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> in cluster cores from X-ray observations. Typical <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> measurements are of order 10% (Maughan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r49\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r49\">2004</a>; Pointecouteau et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r62\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r62\">2004</a>) which give us an <em>M<sub>G</sub></em> estimate of 1.5 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>12</sup>\u2009<em>M</em><sub>\u2609</sub>.</p><p>Finally, we calculate the <em>total</em> <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> ratio within \u03b8<sub>EIN</sub> for the <em>i</em>-band. This yields a value of (<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>)<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 33.7 \u00b1 4.4\u2009(<em>M</em>/<em>L</em>)<sub>\u2609</sub>.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apj404369s5\" name=\"apj404369s5\">5.\u00a0WEAK LENSING MEASUREMENTS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apj404369s5-1\" name=\"apj404369s5-1\">5.1.\u00a0Adaptive Moments</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We used the program Ellipto (Smith et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r69\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r69\">2001</a>) to compute adaptive moments (Bernstein &amp; Jarvis <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r6\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r6\">2002</a>; Hirata et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r31\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r31\">2004</a>) of an object's light distribution, i.e., moments optimized for S/N via weighting by an elliptical Gaussian function self-consistently matched to the object's size. Ellipto computes adaptive moments using an iterative method and runs off of an existing object catalog produced by SExtractor for the given image. Ellipto is also a forerunner of the adaptive moments measurement code used in the SDSS photometric processing pipeline Photo.</p><p>We ran Ellipto on our coadded BCS images and corresponding SExtractor catalogs, doing so independently in each of the <em>griz</em> filters to obtain four separate catalogs of adaptive second moments:\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd6\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd6.gif\" alt=\"Equation (6)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} Q_{xx} & = & \\int x^2 \\ w(x,y) I(x,y) \\, dx\\,dy \\!\\Bigg/\\!\\!\\! \\int w(x,y) I(x,y) \\, dx\\,dy\\nonumber\\\\ \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t6\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p></p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd7\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd7.gif\" alt=\"Equation (7)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} Q_{yy} & = & \\int y^2 \\ w(x,y) I(x,y) \\, dx\\, dy \\!\\Bigg/\\!\\!\\! \\int w(x,y) I(x,y) \\, dx\\,dy\\nonumber\\\\ \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t7\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p></p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd8\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd8.gif\" alt=\"Equation (8)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} Q_{xy} & = & \\int x y \\ w(x,y) I(x,y) \\, dx\\,dy \\!\\Bigg/\\!\\!\\! \\int w(x,y) I(x,y) \\, dx\\,dy,\\nonumber\\\\ \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t8\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>I</em>(<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>) denotes the measured counts of an object at position <em>x</em>, <em>y</em> on the CCD image and <em>w</em>(<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>) is the elliptical Gaussian weighting function determined by Ellipto. The images are oriented with the usual convention that north is up and east is to the left, i.e., right ascension increases along the \u2212<em>x</em>-direction and declination increases along the +<em>y</em>-direction. We then computed the ellipticity components <em>e</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>e</em><sub>2</sub> of each object using one of the standard definitions\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd9\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd9.gif\" alt=\"Equation (9)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} e_1 & = & (Q_{xx} - Q_{yy}) / (Q_{xx} + Q_{yy}) \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t9\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p></p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd10\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd10.gif\" alt=\"Equation (10)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} e_2 & = & 2 Q_{xy} / (Q_{xx} + Q_{yy}). \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t10\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div></div><h3 id=\"apj404369s5-2\" name=\"apj404369s5-2\">5.2.\u00a0PSF Modeling</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>For each filter, we then identified a set of bright but unsaturated stars to use for PSF fitting. We chose the stars from the stellar locus on a plot of the size measure <em>Q<sub>xx</sub></em> + <em>Q<sub>yy</sub></em> from Ellipto versus the magnitude <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt> from SExtractor, using simple cuts on size and magnitude to define the set of PSF stars. We then derived fits of the ellipticities <em>e</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>e</em><sub>2</sub> and the size <em>Q<sub>xx</sub></em> + <em>Q<sub>yy</sub></em> of the stars versus CCD <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> position, using polynomial functions of cubic order in <em>x</em> and <em>y</em> (i.e., the highest-order terms are <em>x</em><sup>3</sup>, <em>x</em><sup>2</sup><em>y</em>, <em>xy</em><sup>2</sup>, and <em>y</em><sup>3</sup>). On each image, these fits were done separately in each of eight rectangular regions, defined by splitting the image area into two parts along the <em>x</em>-direction and into four parts along the <em>y</em>-direction, corresponding to the distribution of the eight Mosaic-II CCDs over the image. This partitioning procedure was needed in order to account for discontinuities in the PSF ellipticity and/or size as we cross CCD boundaries in the Mosaic-II camera. Also note that the individual exposures comprising the final coadded image in each filter were only slightly dithered, so that the CCD boundaries were basically preserved in the coadd. To illustrate the PSF variation in our images, we present in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apj404369f9\">9</a> \"whisker plots\" that show the spatial variation of the magnitude and orientation of the PSF ellipticity across our <em>i</em>- and <em>r</em>-band images. In addition, we also show the residuals in the PSF whiskers remaining after our fitting procedure, showing that the fits have done a good job of modeling the spatial variations of the PSF in our data.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apj404369f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f9_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 9.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369f9_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0Top panels: \"Whisker\" plots that show the clear spatial variation of the PSF ellipticity vs. CCD <em>x</em>, <em>y</em> position in our <em>i</em>- (left) and <em>r</em>-band (right) images. The size of each whisker is proportional to the PSF ellipticity <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn8.gif\" alt=\"$e_{{\\rm PSF}} = \\sqrt{\\vphantom{A^A}\\smash{\\hbox{${e_{1,\\rm PSF}^2 + e_{2,\\rm PSF}^2}$}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">e_{{\\rm PSF}} = \\sqrt{\\vphantom{A^A}\\smash{\\hbox{${e_{1,\\rm PSF}^2 + e_{2,\\rm PSF}^2}$}}}</script></span></span>, where a whisker with ellipticity <em>e</em> = 0.1 is shown at the top center of the figure. Each whisker is oriented at an angle <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"$\\theta _{{\\rm PSF}} = {1}/{2} \\tan ^{-1}(e_{2,\\rm PSF}/e_{1,\\rm PSF})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\theta _{{\\rm PSF}} = {1}/{2} \\tan ^{-1}(e_{2,\\rm PSF}/e_{1,\\rm PSF})</script></span></span> counterclockwise from horizontal. Bottom panels: the corresponding whisker plots after subtraction of the PSF model described in Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apj404369s5-2\">5.2</a>, showing the removal of the bulk of the spatial variation of the PSF ellipticities.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apj404369f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadFigure/figure/apj404369f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apj404369f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/742/1/48/downloadHRFigure/figure/apj404369f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We next used our PSF model to correct our galaxy sizes and ellipticities for the effects of PSF convolution. Specifically, for the size measure <em>Q<sub>xx</sub></em> + <em>Q<sub>yy</sub></em> we used the simple relation (cf. Hirata &amp; Seljak <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r32\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r32\">2003</a>)\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd11\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd11.gif\" alt=\"Equation (11)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} Q_{xx,\\rm true}+Q_{yy,\\rm true} &=& (Q_{xx,\\rm observed}+Q_{yy,\\rm observed})\\nonumber\\\\ &&- (Q_{xx,\\rm PSF}+Q_{yy,\\rm PSF}) \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t11\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>to estimate the true size <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"$Q_{xx,\\rm true}+Q_{yy,\\rm true}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">Q_{xx,\\rm true}+Q_{yy,\\rm true}</script></span></span> of a galaxy from its observed size <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"$Q_{xx,\\rm observed}+Q_{yy,\\rm observed}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">Q_{xx,\\rm observed}+Q_{yy,\\rm observed}</script></span></span>, where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"$Q_{xx,\\rm PSF}+Q_{yy,\\rm PSF}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">Q_{xx,\\rm PSF}+Q_{yy,\\rm PSF}</script></span></span> is obtained from the PSF model evaluated at the <em>x</em>, <em>y</em> position of the galaxy. For the ellipticities, we similarly used the related expressions\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd12\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd12.gif\" alt=\"Equation (12)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} e_{i,\\rm true} & = & \\frac{e_{i,\\rm observed}}{R_2} + \\left(1 - \\frac{1}{R_2} \\right) e_{i,\\rm PSF} \\quad i=1,2 \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t12\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p></p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd13\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd13.gif\" alt=\"Equation (13)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} R_2 & \\equiv & 1 - \\frac{Q_{xx,\\rm PSF}+Q_{yy,\\rm PSF}}{Q_{xx,\\rm observed}+Q_{yy,\\rm observed}}. \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t13\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>The relations used in this simple correction procedure strictly hold only for unweighted second moments, or for adaptive moments in the special case when both the galaxy and the PSF are Gaussians. We have therefore also checked the results using the more sophisticated \"linear PSF correction\" procedure of Hirata &amp; Seljak (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r32\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r32\">2003</a>), which uses additional fourth-order adaptive moment measurements (also provided here by Ellipto) in the PSF correction procedure. In particular, the linear PSF correction method is typically applied in weak lensing analyses of SDSS data. However, we found nearly indistinguishable tangential shear profiles from applying the two PSF correction methods, and we therefore adopted the simpler correction method for our final results.</p></div><h3 id=\"apj404369s5-3\" name=\"apj404369s5-3\">5.3.\u00a0Shear Profiles and Mass Measurements</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Given the estimates of the true galaxy ellipticities from Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd12\">12</a>), we then computed the tangential (<em>e<sub>T</sub></em>) and B-mode or cross (<em>e</em><sub><b>&#x00d7;</b></sub>) ellipticity components, in a local reference frame defined for each galaxy relative to the BCG:\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd14\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd14.gif\" alt=\"Equation (14)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} e_T & = & e_1 \\cos (2\\phi) - e_2 \\sin (2\\phi) \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t14\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p></p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd15\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd15.gif\" alt=\"Equation (15)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray} e_\\times & = & e_1 \\sin (2\\phi) + e_2 \\cos (2\\phi), \\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t15\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /> is the position angle (defined west of north) of a vector connecting the BCG to the galaxy in question. Here we have dropped the subscript <em>true</em> for brevity. The ellipticities were then converted to shears \u03b3 using \u03b3 = <em>e</em>/<em>R</em>, where <em>R</em> is the responsivity, for which we adopted the value <em>R</em> = 2(1 \u2212 \u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub>SN</sub>) = 1.73, using \u03c3<sub>SN</sub> = 0.37 as the intrinsic galaxy shape noise as done in previous SDSS cluster weak lensing analyses (e.g., Kubo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r43\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r43\">2007</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r42\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r42\">2009</a>).</p><p>We then fit our galaxy shear measurements to an NFW profile by minimizing the following expression for \u03c7<sup>2</sup>:\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apj404369fd16\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369fd16.gif\" alt=\"Equation (16)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{equation} \\chi ^2 = \\sum _{i=1}^{N} \\frac{[\\gamma _i - \\gamma _{{\\rm NFW}}(r_i; M_{200},c_{200})]^2}{\\sigma _\\gamma ^2}, \\end{equation}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t16\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where the index <em>i</em> refers to each of the <em>N</em> galaxies in a given sample, <em>r<sub>i</sub></em> is a galaxy's projected physical radius from the BCG (at the redshift of the cluster), \u03c3<sub>\u03b3</sub> is the measured standard deviation of the galaxy shears, and \u03b3<sub>NFW</sub> is the shear given by Equations (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd14\">14</a>)\u2013(<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd16\">16</a>) of Wright &amp; Brainerd (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r72\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r72\">2000</a>) for an NFW profile with mass <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub>. We used a standard Levenberg\u2013Marquardt nonlinear least-squares routine to minimize \u03c7<sup>2</sup> and obtain best-fitting values and errors for the parameters <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> of the NFW profile. Similar fits of the weak lensing radial shear profile to a parameterized NFW model have often been used to constrain the mass distributions of galaxy clusters (e.g., King &amp; Schneider <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r39\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r39\">2001</a>; Clowe &amp; Schneider <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r18\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r18\">2001</a>; Kubo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r42\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r42\">2009</a>; Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r59\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r59\">2009</a>; Okabe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r60\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r60\">2010</a>). Note that we chose the above expression for \u03c7<sup>2</sup> since it does <em>not</em> require us to do any binning in radius, but for presentation purposes below we will have to show binned radial shear profiles compared to the NFW shear profiles obtained from our binning-independent fitting method.</p><p>For the shear fitting analysis, we defined galaxy samples separately in each of the four <em>griz</em> filters using cuts on the magnitude <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt> and on the size <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/742/1/48/Full/apj404369ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"$Q_{xx,\\rm observed}+Q_{yy,\\rm observed}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">Q_{xx,\\rm observed}+Q_{yy,\\rm observed}</script></span></span>, as detailed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apj404369t5\">5</a>. The bright magnitude cut was chosen to exclude brighter galaxies which would tend to lie in the foreground of the cluster and hence not be lensed, while the faint magnitude cuts were set to the photometric completeness limit in each filter, as defined by the turnover magnitude in the histogram of SExtractor <tt>MAG_AUTO</tt> values. For the size cut, we set it so that only galaxies larger than about 1.5 times the PSF size would be used, as has been typically done in SDSS cluster weak lensing analyses (e.g., Kubo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r43\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r43\">2007</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r42\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r42\">2009</a>). Note that in order to properly normalize the NFW shear profile to the measurements, we also need to calculate the critical surface mass density \u03a3<sub>crit</sub>, which depends on the redshifts of the lensed source galaxies as well as the redshift of the lensing cluster; see Equations (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apj404369fd9\">9</a>) and (14) of Wright &amp; Brainerd (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r72\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r72\">2000</a>). To do this, we did not use any individual redshift estimates for the source galaxies in our analysis, but instead we calculated an effective value of 1/\u03a3<sub>crit</sub> via an integral over the source galaxy redshift distribution published for the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS; Ilbert et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apj404369r34\" id=\"fnref-apj404369r34\">2006</a>), as appropriate to the magnitude cuts we applied in each of the <em>griz</em> filters.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apj404369t5\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 5.</b>\u00a0NFW Fit Results</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apj404369t5\"
